did.head: Descriptive Summary
did.unittitle: A Guide to the William Cobbs Letters, 1827-1841

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: William Cobbs Letters, 1827-1841. Accession 41683. Personal papers collection. The Library of Virginia, Richmond, Virginia.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: These items came to the Library of Virginia in a transfer of court papers from the City of Lynchburg.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical Information
bioghist.p: William Cobbs was born March 2, 1792 in Campbell County, Virginia. He attended Hampden-Sydney College. After graduating, Cobbs managed his father's plantations in Campbell and Bedford Counties and his business activities in Kanawha Salines in present-day West Virginia. In 1828, he purchased Poplar Forest from Thomas Jefferson's grandson, Francis Eppes. Cobbs died September 6, 1852 in Bedford County, Virginia.

The letters were used as evidence in a chancery suit entitled John Motley and wife and others versus John P. Cobbs and others that was heard in the Circuit Court of the City of Lynchburg during the 1840's.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Letters, 1827-1841, between William Cobbs and various individuals that relate to the buying, selling, and hiring out of slaves. Several letters also detail how two of Cobbs' slaves ran away and his efforts to recover them. The mental instability of a slave named Harry is also a running theme.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Material
relatedmaterial.p: The chancery suit, John Motley and wife and others versus John P. Cobbs and others, can be found in the Local Records Collection at the Library of Virginia. The index number is City of Lynchburg Chancery Cause 1848-002.
